titleStmt.title: Description of University of Pennsylvania Ms. Codex 1709: Dissertationes medicae.

notesStmt.note: Title from title pages (Volume 1, p. v; Volume 2, p. v).

Volume 1 -- 1. p. ix-x, 1-32: Ague -- 2. p. 33-46: Febris ardens -- 3. p. 47-62: Measles -- 4. p. 63-84: Apthae -- 5. p. 85-110: Phrensy -- 6. p. 111-128: Erysipelas -- 7. p. 129-146: Iliac passion -- 8. p. 147-173: Fluor albus -- Volume 2 -- 1. p. vii-viii, 1-26: Gout -- 2. p. 27-46: Rheumatism -- 3. p. 47-116: Rickets -- 4. p. 117-148: Dysentery -- 5. p. 149-190: Epilepsy -- 6. p. 191-221: Phthisis pulmonalis.

msIdentifier.repository: Kislak Center for Special Collections, Rare Books and Manuscripts

msContents.summary: Descriptions of symptoms and treatment of ailments and diseases, with each section followed by a list of preparations of medicines. Includes references to medical authors such as Sydenham, Boerhaave, Hoffmann, Mauriceau, Albinus, and van Swieten and to Thomas Young (Volume 1, p. 65), professor of midwifery at Edinburgh from 1756 until his death in 1783. Brittleness and ink bleed-through due to oxidation, particularly in the large letters on the section title pages.

supportDesc.extent: 2 volumes (108, 127 leaves) : 160 x 95 (148 x 76) mm bound to 165 x 110 mm
supportDesc.foliation: Paper, 108, 127 leaves; Volume 1, [i-x], 1-173, [174-206]; Volume 2, [i-viii], 1-221, [222-248]; contemporary pagination in ink, modern pagination in pencil, upper outer corners.

layoutDesc.layout: Upper horizontal and vertical bounding lines ruled in lead; first line of text above the upper bounding line on each page.

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Written in cursive script by a single hand.

origin.p: Possibly written in Edinburgh, or elsewhere in Great Britain, after 1756 (Gedge; based on reference to Thomas Young at Edinburgh).

history.provenance: Formerly owned by Edmund Lechmere of Severn End (Worcestershire), 1917 (bookplates, with motto Christus pelicano, inside upper covers).
Sold by Samuel Gedge Ltd. (Hanworth, England), catalog 19 (2014), number 63.
Formerly owned by Norwich surgeon John Green Crosse (signature on title pages, Volume 1, p. v, Volume 2, p. v).
